item.title: Delilah Green Doesn’t Care
item.description: One of those books where the friendships ALMOST outshine the romance. ALMOST. Everybody has arcs and character growth, even the exes; everybody contributes their piece of misunderstanding and conflict resolution to the plot.

item.title: Proper English
item.description: It’s the House Party from Hell, and the first time I read it, I was like this is exhausting, it’s claustrophobic, not sure I can vibe with it—but then I read it again in 2020 and YES.

item.title: Something Fabulous
item.description: So far the theme of the year is romances that I read and then re-read right away and install on my best-of-year list (best-of-ever list too, in the case of Something Fabulous, which more than lives up to its name).

item.title: The Empress of Salt and Fortune
item.description: If you’re partial to storytelling as lush as this cover art, do not miss Nghi Vo. WOW.

item.title: The Sugared Game
item.description: The reason it takes me a week to read a book that I literally can’t put down is because I read it twice.

item.title: A Lady’s Guide to Scandal
item.description: Aah, this was so fun! It righted some wrongs from Persuasion (I’m not a Wentworth fan, okay—don’t @ me), and threw in enough hijinks that it didn’t have to be a faithful retelling.

item.title: A Restless Truth
item.description: This was so close to being great. SO CLOSE. But overall, the book felt kind of like the menagerie on board the ship, let loose in all directions, refusing to be corralled.

item.title: Astrid Parker Doesn’t Fail
item.description: Look, realistically, the destiny stuff did not work for me. They’ve known each other a handful of weeks; saying, “I really, really like you, we’re both hot messes, let’s try to make this work” would have been much more my speed.

item.title: Liberty & Other Stories
item.description: I did not think I could love the [[series/prosperityverse|Prosperityverse]] more, BUT I DO.

item.title: Subtle Blood
item.description: I might have accidentally read Subtle Blood again, since I might have accidentally experienced a vivid dream of Will, Kim, Phoebe, and Maisie on a Parisian adventure (cameo by Teddy Molyneaux, of course), and upon waking, might have accidentally been distraught that that book wasn’t going to exist.

item.title: Clear and Muddy Loss of Love
item.description: This is just what I was in the mood for, a 300+ chapter, 4000 page sapphic slow burn court intrigue. The prose (and/or translation?

item.title: Everyone in This Room Will Someday Be Dead
item.description: This is the most strongly coded [[notes/autism|autistic]] protagonist I’ve read. Especially of the female, high-masking, chronic burnout variety, and undiagnosed. (Or rather, insufficiently diagnosed with anxiety and depression.

item.title: Gwen & Art Are Not in Love
item.description: I think it wobbled a smiiiidge on the landing, a few things felt abrupt and/or undercooked, not to mention the jarring tonal shift into violence, but the ride to get there was super fun.

item.title: Infamous
item.description: This ending was the EXACT ENDING I’ve wanted to see for SO LONG. (Unapologetic all caps.) It took us ages to get there (more on that in a sec) but once we did?

item.title: Interesting Facts about Space
item.description: Me [page 1]: I’m worried I read too much about [[notes/autism|ASD]] into [[books/everyone in this room will someday be dead|Everyone in This Room Will Someday be Dead]].

item.title: Kiss Her Once for Me
item.description: Tried this one again, hoping I had one more festive read in me for the year, but there are just sooo many things that bug me right away.

item.title: Siren Queen
item.description: I’ve been saving this one to be my birthday book because I knew Nghi Vo would deliver. Hoo boy, did she ever.
